text.content: To continue, click another Module, or return to the portal to select another Pillar.
Congratulations! You have completed the Stress module.

Help parents:
  • Realize that learning to cope with stress is an important part of a child's development. Very young infants can't calm down by themselves when they are stressed. They depend on adults to help their stress response to become regulated. With time, the comfort and care they receive helps them to develop a well-functioning stress response system.
• Know and understand the different kinds of responses to stress so they can help and support children with their experiences with each type.

• Teach children coping skills that can help buffer them from unhealthy amounts of stress. Early parental support and involvement is the most important factor in regulating a child's physiological stress response.
• Understand that children depend on caregivers to help them learn how to identify sources of stress, cope with their feelings and reactions, and learn strategies to self-regulate and feel calm.

graphic.notes: Stress image from the Stress folder

audio.transcript: Congratulations! You have completed the Stress module. In this module you should have learned more about the biology of stress and the impact of stress on a child's development. Before we move on, let's review some of the main ideas.

First, help parents realize that learning to cope with stress is an important part of a child's development. Very young infants can't calm down by themselves when they are stressed. They depend on adults to help their stress response to become regulated. With time, the comfort and care they receive helps them to develop a well-functioning stress response system.
Next, it is important for parents to know and understand the different kinds of responses to stress so they can help and support children with their experiences with each type.

Furthermore, parents can teach children coping skills that can help buffer them from unhealthy amounts of stress and can focus on helping the child manage the feelings related to the stressful event. Early parental support and involvement is the most important factor in regulating a child's physiological stress response.

Finally, help parents understand that children depend on caregivers to help them learn how to identify sources of stress, cope with their feelings and reactions, and learn strategies to self-regulate and feel calm. Children depend on adults to help them regulate their stress response, and the younger they are, the more help they need.
If you have questions about any of these concepts, please review the Educator Training Goals by clicking the Professional Icon before moving on to the next pillar.

text.content:
Educator Training Goals:

Identify the three types of stress that affect the developing child.

Explain the impact of repeated, long-term stress on children.

Explain how parental support and involvement helps to regulate an infantâ€™s stress responses through calming and self-soothing.

Communicate the importance of teaching parents the role that stress plays in a young child's social and emotional development.

Help parents learn to identify their own stress.

You should complete Assessment 1 before beginning another pillar. You can access the assessments and other pillars from the Parenting Counts Portal.
